intro: Astragalus conjunctus var. conjunctus, commonly known as the western jointleaf paintbrush, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its distinctive, fern-like leaves and showy, spurred flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to arid environments. It plays a role in local ecosystems by providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a host plant for certain insects. Its botanical features make it an important species for ecological studies and conservation efforts.
